awd_titl_txt: RUI: Two-dimensional flow-boiling characteristics under surface wettability gradient
awd_abstract_narration:
As technology becomes increasingly miniaturized, extremely concentrated power consumption from advanced electronic devices leads to the challenge of how to keep devices from overheating. Conventional thermal solutions are inadequate for advanced high power density semiconductor devices for wireless and military applications. Flow-boiling, highly efficient phase-changing thermal energy conversion/transport phenomena, can be incorporated into microgap heat-sink technique as a promising thermal solution for high power density electronics. However, local excessive evaporations (dry-outs) by highly concentrated heat sources and consequent unevenness in flow distribution has been a challenging issue. In this project, microgap surface wetting property will be modified to address this issue; i.e., highly wetting surfaces imposed on hot-spots will enhance liquid-phase entrainment and thus prevent dry-out. The successful accomplishment of this project will advance fundamental knowledge in complex multiphase flow and heat transfer, enable cooling of futuristic electronic devices, and transfer state-of-the-art knowledge and experience to undergraduate and K-12 students.

The objective of this project is to attain fundamental knowledge about two-dimensional flow-boiling morphology and heat transfer characteristics under a surface wettability gradient. Despite the critical importance, the understanding of 2-D flow-boiling morphological behavior is very limited. Mere extension of 1-D theories cannot accommodate the 2-D complications and consequences. The proposed research tasks will investigate the 2-D flow-boiling morphology and vapor ebullition cycle, which will explain 2-D energy transport mechanisms related to the flow-boiling. The effect of multiphase forces on the vapor dispersion behaviors will be explored as well. Microgap surfaces with various wetting properties will be fabricated and tested to study how the induced capillary force modify the multiphase force balance and eventually affect 2-D flow-boiling phenomena.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
Two-phase cooling or flow-boiling in micro-spaces utilizes the highly efficient thermal energy transport of phase change from liquid to vapor. However, the excessive consumption of liquid-phase by highly localized heat source causes the two-phase flow maldistribution, leading to a greatly reduced heat transfer coefficient, high-pressure loss, and limited flow rate. In this study, we have investigated two-dimensional flow-boiling in a microgap heat sink with different hydrophilic coating on hot-spot and characterize the bubble morphology, heat transfer, and pressure drop. The experiments have been conducted on a stainless-steel plate micro gap using deionized water at room temperature. A partial hydrophilic and a hydrophilic channel surface are created on the hot-spot (surface above the heater) to compare the thermal performance with the conventional surface. The relative thermal performance and wettability change between the hydrophilic surfaces are also evaluated. From the high-speed flow visualizations, it is found that vapor films and slugs are flushed quickly from the hydrophilic surfaces, which improve heat transfer on hydrophilic heat sink compared to the conventional heat sink. It is also evaluated that among the hydrophilic heat sinks, channel hydrophilic heat sink shows better cooling performance and pressure stability as it provides a smooth route for the incoming water to cool the hot spot. The key findings of this study are listed follows, 

  • Vapor film generates on the hot spot of conventional heat sink which indicates a short term partial dry out which lasts longer at high heat fluxes. However, on partial and channel hydrophilic heat sinks it is found only initially at very high heat flux. The vapor films are flushed very quickly from hydrophilic surfaces compared to conventional. Among the hydrophilic surfaces, vapor films are flushed more quickly from the channel hydrophilic surface compared to partial hydrophilic. 
  • The flow visualization shows the flow transition from bubbly to slug flow in this flow. These slugs are responsible to increase the wall temperature and pressure drop. Due to whole hydrophilic coated surface from inlet to outlet on channel hydrophilic heat sink, water gets a smooth route to pass through the hot spot which helps to remove more slugs easily. So, channel hydrophilic surface can mitigate hot spot temperature more than the other two surfaces. 
  • Hydrophilic treated surface provides improved cooling performance by taking away more heat from the surface. From the cooling performance profile, it can be inferred that maximum local temperature drop occurs on channel hydrophilic surface. 
  • Heat transfer coefficient (h) increases significantly on channel hydrophilic heat sinks at lower heat flux region except for low mass flux. Overall, h increases on channel hydrophilic surface around 5% to 14% compared to conventional heat sink at low heat fluxes. Again, compared to partial hydrophilic heat sink, h increases around 2% to 10%. The h goes down on hydrophilic heat sinks at very high heat fluxes due the saturated unchanged liquid film remains at the hot spot under vapor film. 
  • The normalized average differential pressure decreases with the increase of heat fluxes on conventional and partial hydrophilic heat sink but less variation is observed on channel hydrophilic heat sink. This is because of quick slug flushing and low pressure instability on channel hydrophilic surface. 
  • Average contact angle increases more after test for partial hydrophilic case which denotes higher degradation of wettability compared to channel hydrophilic. At low mass flux, wettability deteriorates more for both hydrophilic surfaces compared to high mass flux. 

Last Modified: 09/14/2022
Modified by: Jong-Hoon Kim
por.por_txt_cntn:
Two-phase cooling or flow-boiling in micro-spaces utilizes the highly efficient thermal energy transport of phase change from liquid to vapor. However, the excessive consumption of liquid-phase by highly localized heat source causes the two-phase flow maldistribution, leading to a greatly reduced heat transfer coefficient, high-pressure loss, and limited flow rate. In this study, we have investigated two-dimensional flow-boiling in a microgap heat sink with different hydrophilic coating on hot-spot and characterize the bubble morphology, heat transfer, and pressure drop. The experiments have been conducted on a stainless-steel plate micro gap using deionized water at room temperature. A partial hydrophilic and a hydrophilic channel surface are created on the hot-spot (surface above the heater) to compare the thermal performance with the conventional surface. The relative thermal performance and wettability change between the hydrophilic surfaces are also evaluated. From the high-speed flow visualizations, it is found that vapor films and slugs are flushed quickly from the hydrophilic surfaces, which improve heat transfer on hydrophilic heat sink compared to the conventional heat sink. It is also evaluated that among the hydrophilic heat sinks, channel hydrophilic heat sink shows better cooling performance and pressure stability as it provides a smooth route for the incoming water to cool the hot spot. The key findings of this study are listed follows, 

Vapor film generates on the hot spot of conventional heat sink which indicates a short term partial dry out which lasts longer at high heat fluxes. However, on partial and channel hydrophilic heat sinks it is found only initially at very high heat flux. The vapor films are flushed very quickly from hydrophilic surfaces compared to conventional. Among the hydrophilic surfaces, vapor films are flushed more quickly from the channel hydrophilic surface compared to partial hydrophilic. 
The flow visualization shows the flow transition from bubbly to slug flow in this flow. These slugs are responsible to increase the wall temperature and pressure drop. Due to whole hydrophilic coated surface from inlet to outlet on channel hydrophilic heat sink, water gets a smooth route to pass through the hot spot which helps to remove more slugs easily. So, channel hydrophilic surface can mitigate hot spot temperature more than the other two surfaces. 
Hydrophilic treated surface provides improved cooling performance by taking away more heat from the surface. From the cooling performance profile, it can be inferred that maximum local temperature drop occurs on channel hydrophilic surface. 
Heat transfer coefficient (h) increases significantly on channel hydrophilic heat sinks at lower heat flux region except for low mass flux. Overall, h increases on channel hydrophilic surface around 5% to 14% compared to conventional heat sink at low heat fluxes. Again, compared to partial hydrophilic heat sink, h increases around 2% to 10%. The h goes down on hydrophilic heat sinks at very high heat fluxes due the saturated unchanged liquid film remains at the hot spot under vapor film. 
The normalized average differential pressure decreases with the increase of heat fluxes on conventional and partial hydrophilic heat sink but less variation is observed on channel hydrophilic heat sink. This is because of quick slug flushing and low pressure instability on channel hydrophilic surface. 
Average contact angle increases more after test for partial hydrophilic case which denotes higher degradation of wettability compared to channel hydrophilic. At low mass flux, wettability deteriorates more for both hydrophilic surfaces compared to high mass flux. 


					Last Modified: 09/14/2022

					Submitted by: Jong-Hoon Kim
